captions.text:
71% of people who graduated from college in
2012 have student loan debt. Full disclosure,

I have quite a lot. Like, so much. The average
graduate borrowed around $29,000. The total

number of student loans owed in the US today
has surpassed 1 trillion dollars with numbers

rising every year. It’s reasonable to expect
that some if not many of those borrowers will

have to default on their debt at some point.
So, what will that look like? How bad is defaulting
on your student loans?

It’s pretty bad. Most students use federal
loans to pay for their education, and the

Federal Government has many ways to get back
its money. The Treasury Offset Program allows

the US Department of the Treasury to take
your tax refund and give it directly to the

Department of Education to pay down your loan.
They are also legally allowed to garnish up

to about 15% your wages, which means taking
money directly out of your paycheck. Some

states also allow private loan companies to
seize your state tax refund in the same way.

And if for some reason the Federal Government
or a private company doesn’t think that

any of these previous methods are quick enough,
they can sue you for the full amount at any
time.

So, even if you default, the Government and
these private companies are still going to
get their money.

And that is just the beginning. Defaulting
on any loan will have a negative effect on

your credit score, which will make it harder
for you to take out money in the future, to

buy a house or a car, or start a business.
It may even affect your chances of landing
a job or an apartment.

And there is no safety valve that can get
you out of student loan debt. Bankruptcy cannot

help you - even after you’ve liquidated
all of your assets to resolve your other debts,

you still have to pay your student loans.
So, you really shouldn’t default on your

student loans. If you are unable to pay them
but they are not yet in default you have options.

There are scenarios in which you can qualify
for loan modification, deferment, or forgiveness.

It’s always good to contact your lender
before defaulting on a loan, since working

with you to get their money back is in their
best interest, and yours.

With all of that said, if you have to borrow
money for school, federal student loans are

the best option, as far as affordability and
credibility are concerned. Just make sure
to work with them so that you don’t default.

If you care about saving money and want to
help the show. Check out our sponsor Ting.

Go to testtube.ting.com to see how much you’ll
save on phone service. If you do that now,

you'll get $25 off a new device or $25 in
service credit. There are no hidden ‘admin

fees’ or sketchy charges. Ting only charges
you Usage + $6 per device + tax each month.
Ting: Mobile that makes sense.

If you’d like to see more TestTube, please
click on our episode about the minimum wage

and why we should or should not raise it.
New videos five days a week please subscribe.

title: What Happens If You Don't Pay Off Your Student Loans?

comments.text:
Higher education isn't for everyone. It can be useful in certain fields, 
but in general it's unlikely that your degree with be necessary. Nearly 
half of graduates (including myself) don't utilize their degrees, yet the 
politically correct thing to do is to tell everyone to go to college. That 
raises the cost of tuition. Even worse is when federal and state 
governments offer easy loans for those who clearly can't afford a high 
priced school, pushing tuition even higher. Law School seems to be the 
worst deal of all, charging sky-high prices and promising six-figure 
incomes when it's more likely the student will earn the salary of a 
high-school teacher. 

That being said, there are a number of great schools for higher education 
in the U.S. that we should be proud of. In term of quality, only the U.K. 
comes close. There are even a number of publicly-funded universities in the 
U.S. that beat top universities of some Western European countries for 
quality.﻿

comments.text:
What's the usual interest rate on U.S. student debt, out of interest? I ask 
so that I can compare it with the UK, with my BSc and MSc I have £25000 in 
debt from undergrad with an interest rate of 0% above inflation, and £10750 
with an interest rate of 6.71% APR from my MSc. The current interest rate 
is 1.49 dollars to the pound. Would you guys say this is generally better 
or worse than the U.S. system? Also the tuition fee cap was increased 
to £9000, so if I had gone to University a year later then it would 
be £41500 at 0% above inflation and still £10750 at 6.71% APR, how does 
that compare?﻿

comments.author: ImoenOfTelengard

comments.text:
Please only accept subsidized loans (accumulates interest AFTER 
graduation). Try to avoid unsubsidized loans (accumulates interest Everyday 
and After graduation). Deduct interest from taxes. Please avoid 
out-of-state tuition, private student loans, and for-profit colleges like 
Everest and ITT Tech. Take courses at community colleges (they are legit). 
To get more aid, prove struggles of parents (or yourself) to financial aid 
office: Foreclosure, repossession, bankruptcy, debt settlements, 
separation, divorces, death, new child, hospitalization, unemployment, 
reduction in income, food stamps, failure to pay taxes, wage garnishment, 
incarcerations, terminal illness or condition, etc. Choose credit unions. 
Banks are for-profit. Do not drop out of college = Less likely to repay 
debts.﻿

courses to satisfy requirements towards your Bachelor’s degree (some 
programs at allow this).﻿
comments.author: Danny Singh

comments.text:
I thought I'd give a transatlantic comparison. The UK.

Our equivalent to Federal loans is the Student Loans Company, run by the UK 
Government. Currently, the max per annum tuition fee is £9k($13.5k). The 
poorest students can apply for fee waivers or grants from their university. 
[A quick note, the highest fee was £3k/yr ($4.4k/yr) prior to 2010, the 
Deputy Prime Minister, who signed a pledge not to increase the fee, has 
constituency with a high student population - the UK elections are in a few 
weeks].

As the UK has a system of devolution, each of the 4 nations can decide how 
much of the tuition students in their country pay. Scotland has chosen to 
make tuition free for all Scottish students, England chose the maximum and 
Wales/Northern Ireland are somewhere in the middle.

However, all loans are administered the same way. All fees are paid to 
institutions on a student's behalf, you don't have to take out personal 
loans. As an EU citizen, the same applies if I want to travel abroad to a 
European university for a term(semester). You can get funding through the 
Eramus Programme.

The interest rate is 3-5% and the debt does not affect your credit rating 
score. The new system means you'll only pay back loans on your income above 
£21k($31). If you fall below this, your repayments stop. After 30 or so 
years, the slate is wiped clean.﻿

comments.author: foshastajones

comments.text:
It's not like people have a choice; millions of graduates would love to 
work but there's just no work for them (either that or they work some 
shitty low-paying job in the services industry.)  The reasons for this are 
complicated (human action is complicated) but to sum it up, the state makes 
everything expensive (taxes & regulations & inflation & welfare & war & 
corporate favors et al) which in turn makes it hard for existing businesses 
to make a profit (they lay-off or worse, close down) and makes it hard for 
new businesses to start (higher barrier to entry.)  Even just recently, 
major internet companies like Comcast are now benefiting from the so-called 
"net neutrality" (just bumping up the internet into "public utility" 
classification) in that the cost of developing a new internet company has 
shot way up, meaning less competition for existing corporations, meaning 
greater profit margins for them but overall Americans are worse off since 
their already shitty internet at outrageous prices are going to get 
shittier and yet more expensive; why should they improve?  What are you 
going to do, go to another company?  There is no other company!

From what I can tell, most Americans wanted this to happen, because, 
y'know, the market is evil and all that.  So unless Americans pull up their 
pants and strap on their big boy belts and start accepting that life 
involves risk, that no government can ever protect them from that, which I 
doubt will happen soon enough to turn this sinking ship around, then you 
shouldn't be worried about paying off your debts, because you likely never 
will; at this point you're lucky to make ends meet on your own.  This is 
not even considering the national debt which has exceeded the point of no 
return, but I guess we're not going to talk about that.  What happens when 
the U.S. government can't pay its bills (esp. consider its military bill) 
because no nation wants to lend us money anymore and there are too few 
businesses left to pick up the tax burden?

That's right kiddies, no more USA, at least not as we know it.  But fuck 
it, good riddance; no American likes how things are now anyway, ironically 
despite being the #1 cause of its woes (no, it's not the politicians, it's 
not the feds, it's not the banks, it's not the corporations, it's 
Americans, who give these people power over them); corruption is rampant, 
we're all broke (you're lucky to be just broke, a ton of you guys are even 
worse off than that), constantly depressed, tired from working too much, 
unsatisfied with just about everything.  No regime ever lasts long under 
these conditions; I just hope you guys don't pull a Germany and 
democratically elect Hitler incarnate.  There's no Superman who will save 
you; change starts at home.﻿

another country. This should shock the conscience of any reasonable minded,

comments.text:
Why do americans borrow money for school? Are books for college really 
expensive in the US? My med school books are all over 4,500 MXN, about 
maybe 300 USD, and 2 books of mine are 12,000 MXN, like 800 USD. Are 
colleges in the US all private or have to pay a hefty fee? In my school I 
only pay literally 50 cents of a Mexican peso (0.3 cents in USD). For a 
full year. UNAM. and my university UNAM is the best in Mexico and in the 
top 5 of latin america, definteley not comparing Mexicos Universities with 
United States, the top Universites of the World are in the US but, why is 
college so expensive in the US? I have a friend thats from Panama and he is 
renting an apartment for 16,000 MXN (about 1,200 USD) a month. And food is 
relativity cheap in Mexico.

And transportation, I spend 10 pesos every day to get on the Metro. Less 
than a dollar.﻿

comments.author: Barny Elbourn

comments.text:
Two points: (1) Dispite its expense, advanced education is still vitally 
important for individual job seekers as well as society as a whole.  
However, we need to rethink how we approach education.  As someone with 
multiple degrees and a mountain of student debt, my best recommendation to 
all prospective students who do not have access to affordable education is 
to ignore everyone who says you need to take out loans and get your degree 
in 4 years or less.  Make staying debt free an equal priority to getting 
your education.  This of course, will require that you work at least part 
time while going to school part time, find cheaper substitutes for books 
and learning materials, live at home or in cheap/shared housing, ride a 
bike when possible, eat cheap, attend schools with the lowest cost per 
credit hour, etc.  This is also your best way of boycotting the for-profit 
education/lending insustry in the US.  In order to get cheaper loans and 
more student friendly student loan laws, we must make the industry compete 
for our business.  The only way to do that is take your business away from 
them.  Otherwise, the industry will continue to abuse its captive consumers.
(2)  While it is true that student loans are generally non-dischargeable in 
bankruptcy, there is one hardship exception that students with special 
economic circumstances such as large medical bills, serious health 
problems or other serious obstacle to repayment should talk to a qualified 
bankruptcy attorney about.  However, this exception is rather difficult to 
meet.  Bankruptcy rules, including the hardship exception mentioned above, 
became much harder on students since 2005 due to lobbying efforts by the 
lending industry which successfully achieved far more creditor friendly 
rules.  These are the same lenders that caused the Great Recession that is 
still making it difficult for new graduates to find jobs to pay off those 
excessively large and high interest student loans.  Schools and lenders 
should be held at least partly responsible for selling students on a highly 
expensive and largely financed education that fails to deliver good paying 
jobs.﻿
